He does not stand off and criticize and find fault with their play, but enters right into their amusement and if he finds one who is mischievous he sets him in order and teaches him that he must play right. And thus the teachers mingle with the scholars in their amusement and their hearts are bound together.--Ms 19, 1887, pp. 7, 8. ("A Practical Education," August 18, 1887.)
